2. MERCREDI. 
We marched from L'Estrade, where we had been since the 16th Dec 1917, and joined the main body of the amb at the Div Rest Station at 
Ravelsberg
near Bailleul. The camp is formed of army huts, and is close to a fairly large aerodrome. Aeroplanes in the air, perhaps twenty at a time arouse little interest among the accustomed troops and civilians.
Entry.3:
At Ravelsberg billeted in huts, each with stove.
Sometimes we walk into the town of Bailleul to see a divisional pierrot show or YMCA pictures. This town had a pre war population of nearly 15,000 now much smaller, despite the trade done with the British troops.
Eng. Leave commences for the unit at rate of 9 men per week.
Entry.4:
Our routine is:-
Reveille 7.30 am
Breakfast 8.15 porridge & bacon, or stew, bread, tea
Parade 8.45
Dinner 12.30 pm stew, curry or roast beef, vegetables scarce perhaps rice or sago pudding, biscuits (army), jam, margarine, tea
Tea : Rice or sago, jam tea etc.
Lights out 9.30 pm

19 MARDI. 
B & C. Sections fell in at huts at Westhof about 9am and marched through Romarin & Ploegsteert past Charing Cross round Hyde Park Corner to Red Lodge Advance Dressing Station. Or rather C section did and B section marched on thro' Ploegesteert to Old Brewery & Motor Car corner advance dressing stations. From Red Lodge I was sent to a relay post.

20 MERCREDI. 
Stationed at "PillBox" Relay post with Jack Perry. Ron Ponton & Harold Best. This pill box a very comfortable habitation is situated on the 
bank
south bank of the River Douve which runs between Hill 63 & Hill 65 (Messines Ridge) to join the River Lys somewhere near Warneton. This pill box had been a machine gun & observation post before its capture by our brigade in the Battle of Messines
Entry.52:
JEUDI. 
We lived in this very strong concrete dugout very happily for 2 days, doing our own cooking & only having 3 walking cases. Then our relief arriving we moved on, during the morning to the 40th RAP called Douve RAP. This dug out is constructed of elephant iron & dirt the space being cut into the side of a embankment of the Douve which runs almost

th
in front of the door.
Entry.53:
VENDREDI. 
Here we also stayed for two days having a quiet pleasant time with only two stretcher cases to take down to the relay post. This RAP was well back from the front line — nearly 1000 yards.
The AMC detail were in charge of a brigade YMCA free cocoa & biscuit stall & of course we benefited. We did our own cooking on a primus stove.
I progressed with my 
1917
 diary.

Our abode was a cellar arranged with wire bunks and fitted with a table & electric light supplied by the Catacombs huge dugouts under Hill 63, about ½ a mile away

at

MARDI. 
At our billets in wooden huts just behind Nieppe village. Put on fatigue washing down waggons.
Afternoon: attended dentists,
Received watch from Wagstaffe, who had had it mended in Blighty for me.
Evening: wrote up old diary.

– Nieppe, Leave – (Self)

FEVRIER
Entry.58:
MERCREDI. 
At Nieppe – a village between Armentieres & Bailleul & about 4 miles behind the line. It was here that a great number of civilians were killed just before the Battle of Messines by the enemy bombardment.
Was detailed for fatigue but spent my time at the dentists & cleaning up a bit for Blighty
Entry.59:
Proceeded on leave to Eng
Obtained leave pass for 1-15 March leave ticket sugar permit etc & was taken with the 3 others going to Steenwerck Station. Here were entrained in trucks with seats, leaving at 11 am.
Arrived Calais we marched to the rest camp & had dinner but immediately paraded again & marched to the leave boat which left at 5.30 arriving at Dover Pier at 7pm, & by 10.15 we were at Victoria Stn London

Con The Australians were marched to Hqrs at Horseferry Road & it was past midnight before we had had our passes stamped were lectured & given supper.

MARS
Entry.60:
I slept that night at AIF & War Chest Club, a fine club opp HQrs & having 1000 beds. Arriving very late I drew pay & clothing, had dinner & went to see Miss Doyle.
Then I walked up through Westminster along Whitehalll, past Trafalgar Square to the Strand to the American "Eagle Hut" YMCA. Here I had tea & spent the night very comfortably, first going to see the "Beauty Spot" a musical play at the Gaity next door.
Entry.61:
SAMEDI. 
On Leave
Went to Commonwealth Bank in Australia House & drew £5, and for a walk up Strand & Fleet St. Then went out to Tulse Hill to see Mrs M. I had lunch with her & then returned to Euston Station & took 4pm train through pretty country to Northhampton & Stafford to Crewe. It was now dark, & after changing trains here here we passed thro' Chester arriving at my destination Llandudno at 11pm. Here I stayed at "The Raven".

Llandudno is a large modern & very attractive watering place on the N Wales Coast. The prettiest parts are the Great Orme, a big headland & "The Happy Valley" an artificial garden upon it. 

MARS
Entry.62:
DIMANCHE 
The pier & promenade are also very fine. Being Sunday I went to the Eng Baptist Chapel & in the afternoon I walked over about 3 miles to Conway. Conway is a very quaint & historic little town. It is still a Royal borough & the old castle still towers over the entrance to the Conway River which is now spanned by a very fine suspension bridge & a tubular railway bridge. 
I spc
 The town walls still stand & are very interesting. I spent the evening yarning with owners of a tea shop & returned to Llandudno.
Entry.63:
LUNDI. 
An early breakfast & I caught the 7.40 train to Carnarvon. The train trip is very pleasant lying along the coast. Carnarvon is like Conway quaint & historic but the castle is much more elaborate & in better preservation. After lunch I returned to Menai Bridge & took the train to Holyhead crossing the bridge. The boat left at 2.30 arriving at Kingstown at 5.30 & by 6pm I was at the Soldiers & Sailors Central Club in Dublin for tea. Then went to the theatre & returned to bed.

MARS
Entry.64:
MARDI. 
10 am A professional guide took us in hand for the day. We walked up the River Liffey past the Four Courts inclg the Law Courts to St Michans Church where we saw the vaults containing coffins & bodies never buried or treated in any way but in perfect preservation. From here we went first to Christchurch Cathedral & then to St Patricks, both being Church of Ireland (Prot)
After dinner we visited the Bank of Ireland in the Old House of Irish Parl then Trinity College with its museum. We also saw through the municipal Art Gallery & then went along to Nelsons Pillar. Other places we saw were Dunster Park & Dublin "Castle" a collection of Imperial Offices. Theatre again & then attended a robust Republican meeting.
Entry.65:
MERCREDI. 
After breakfast at the club, I went out by tram to Phoenix Park. This park is very fine & large having beautiful drives & containing the Zoo Gdns which I visited. Other features are a splendid equestrian statue to General Gough from guns capt'd in Crimea and a tremendous memorial to Wellington. Then ret'g to Dublin I laboriously ascended the Nelson Pillar & was rewarded with a fine view of the city. After dinner (food is abundant in Ireland) I caught the 3pm train to 
Dub
Belfast. The trip was mostly along flat seaside country not over interesting taking 2½-3 hours. From the G N Stn I walked to the Belfast Sol & Sailors Services Club had tea: secured a good bed, & then went to the Gaiety Theatre
Entry.66:
Visited the splendid new City Hall with its fine marble panelled entrance hall & staircases & elaborate civic apartments. Then I went to another
7 JEUDI. 
prominent structure – the Assembly Building (Presby Ch of Ireland). With its oval hall to seat 2000 & fine offices it is a model.
Afternoon:
I visited the Ulster Volunteer Forces Hospital, Queens College (Uni), & saw Meth College, visited Botanic Gdns & the splendid large Ormeau Park. Then returned through some suburbs by 2 decker elect tram, visited the Albert Memorial & ret'd to Club & wrote home.
Belfast
is an admirable prosperous growing city with narrow convenient streets, few fine buildings, ornamental churches, & clean modern terraced suburbs! I slept at soldiers club.
Entry.67:
VENDREDI. 
From the City Chamberlain I obtained permits & with two Canadians in the morning visited the York St Flax Spinning Mills & saw linen made. Then in the afternoon on we went through the Belfast Ropeworks. Then returning to town we parted. I took the tram out about 5 miles to Cave Hill an eminence from which a glorious view of Belfast Lough is obtained. Back in the city I had a good walk round then at 9pm caught the boat for Ardrossan in Scotland. The trip was smooth

but cold & performed with none but port & starboard lights. My parcel of little gifts packed for Aussy was stolen.

MARS
Entry.68:
Arrived at Ardrossan at 4.30 am, and an hours train run brought us to the Central Station, Glasgow. Having had no sleep I went to the fine big Central Hotel on the Station. Then slept till 2pm, bathed & had a late luncheon.
For the remainder of the afternoon I walked round the city. Then went to the large YMCA for tea, did some writing & slept there. I secured a book on the history of the clans. 
Glasgow
is a big city of very fine bldgs well laid out on a number of hills. It impressed me as much like Sydney. The tram service is very complete & cheap. The underground is old fashioned!
Entry.69:
DIMANCHE. 
With a party from the YMCA we went by tram through the town of Dumbarton with its historic hill & castle by the Clyde, up the vale of Leven to the village of Balloch, the distance being about 14 miles, From Balloch we took a steam launch up the lake for about 8 miles & were then in the Highlands.
The Loch
seen in an off season was not over attractive with its brown water & barren brown enclosing hills. Ben Lomond standing at the head of the Loch. Returned to town & slept at Cal Temperance Hotel

Still on leave (Self)

MARS
Entry.70:
In Glasgow walked round town trying to buy new books 
or
 and a history of the Clan Maclean. Caught noon tram for Stirling. Visited the Royal Palace of Stirling Castle (now used as barracks & spent a delightful hour or so examining the place & admiring the wonderful view which included the Vale of Menteith, Stirling Bge, Wallace Memorial, Field of Bannockburn, Menteith River & the Grampian Highlands in the distance.
I returned to city, went walk, then to Empire Theatre & to YMCA
Entry.71:
MARDI. 
Caught 9.0 train from St Enoch Station & arrived in Carlisle about 12 noon, after a very pretty run through Ayrshire and then through the Cumberland Hills. At Carlisle I had a look round & dinner at the Food Control 
Kitchen
 
Re
 "Tavern" Restaurant. At 2 pm I caught the train on to Manchester. The trip lay first through extremely pretty country 
then
 on to Preston then on to Bolton & through the Black Country arriving at 5.30pm. Went to the YM in Piccadilly & meeting some mates went to "Romance"

Manchester
 impressed me as a fine city of splendid buildings & modern warehouses, clean but in a dirty district.

MARS
Entry.72:
. 
In Manchester
visited the Town Hall a fine big building with small but lofty hall, also the Cathedral small but having fine windows. Then I went out by tram to Alexandra Park in a suburb.
At 2.15 I caught the train for London. The trip lay through dry barren hilly country to Sheffield a dirty town indeed then on to Nottingham & Leicester. The country became more agricultural, flatter but prettier & we arrived at Marylebone Stn at 7pm. Visited Shakespeare Hut lodged at Holborn YMCA & went to the "Empire"
Entry.73:
After breakfast at the Holborn YM I walked up Holborn to Ludgate Circus thence to Petticoat Lane (market day – Sunday only) & so to Aldgate & 
by
 via Bank of Eng etc thro Strand Piccadilly & 
Gros
 Buckingham Palace to Victoria Station.
Afternoon: Visited Harold Luart at Camberwell (No 1 LGH) then returned walked West End met Mrs & Miss M, had dinner at Lyons Corner House & returned to AIF & War Chest Club in Westminster & wrote home.
Entry.74:
I should have returned to France but had a late rising instead & paraded sick at HQ & managed to get another day's leave.
15 VENDREDI. 
Walked up Victoria Street to Westminster. Went through quickly & then up Whitehall to Prime Ministers homely office No 10 Downing St. then to Trafalgar & Leicester Squares round all the theatres to Covent Garden.
I had lunch at the Eagle Hut (USA YMCA) then took tube to Mde. Tussauds Waxworks & spent the afternoon among the models. Returned to the city for tea & went to Chu Chin Chow at His Majestys & returned to AIF Club.
Entry.75:
SAMEDI
. 
Returning from Leave 
Caught 8am train from Victoria Station, arriving at Dover about 11 am. We were marched up to one of the big barracks on the hill, & lodged here till next day. The afternoon & evening we were able to spend in Dover & climbing the chalk cliffs beside the town. These are very high & fortified. The harbour is mainly naval. The town is very quaint with small houses & shops & narrow winding streets & tramways.

 

Self (At 
Dover
 Calais & St Omer returning from leave)

MARS
Entry.76:
DIMANCHE. 
About 9 am we marched down to the wharf & an hour from leaving found us waiting for a while in Calais Roads. We marched to No 3 Rest Camp, had dinner & were safely lodged behind barb wire for a day, in tents sunk in the sand with no occupation but to watch the Chows in the opposite camp. The Camp YMCA was in great demand. I attended service there.
Entry.77:
LUNDI. 
After an early dinner we were marched to the railway station through the outskirts of the town, & obtained tea from the canteen. Starting about 3pm we arrived at St Omer about 5pm & 
had
 were quartered at the Vet Hospital.
For the remainder of the day we had leave. I went up to the Church Army Cinema after obtaining some tea. Before tea I went for a walk in the Gardens which are very fine having pleasant walks in a small woods

Returning from leave St Omer to Brunembert

MARS
Entry.78:
MARDI. 
5am reveille. 6am boarded train starting for Boulogne, arriving at Desvres about 12.
At the 
leave
 camps for reinforcements I found Jim 
Prent
 Beatty in charge there. Walking down to the square I obtained some dinner & then walked out 5 miles in the rain to our ambulance's billets at the small village of Brunembert, north of Desvres. Here I found the section billeted in the attics of farm houses. The district is hilly & green & pretty.
Entry.79:
MERCREDI. 
Morning: we had a bath parade to a neighbouring village. Afternoon: played football. Evening: held concert in a room we had hired in the village for writing etc. I had received an Aussy mail 27th January – some parcels so was happy.
Entry.80:
I Route march in morning & sports in afternoon.

 

Train to Caistre Marc'd to Watteau

MARS
Entry.81: Morning: early reveille & commenced packing the units gear. Then told to have a rest. Afternoon: Completing packing 8pm. Fell in on road & marched with one halt & much abuse for the CO to Lottinghem Railway Station, & waited round about the station till about 2am the next day when
Entry.82:
We were told to sleep till 6am.
We waited till 10 am & then entrained & came to Caistre about 1 pm. From here we marched without packs to Godesvaersvelde near Mt. des Catts in France and from here to Watteau in Belgium. Here we had tea & turned in to bed early in good billets.

To Wallon-Cappel

MARS
Entry.83:
We fell in about 9am & marched a few kilos out of the village, 
Here but only the infantry
 Here we boarded motor lorries down to Wallon-Cappel a village between Hazebrouck & St Omer. We arrived here about 2 pm & were billeted in barns.
Entry.84:
LUNDI. 
Resting at Wallon-Cappel
We were told we were going into the thick of the battle, which had now developed into open warfare as the enemy had forced a considerable advance through our line for 50 miles south of Arras. We were told to conserve our food & water, & throw away every thing with which we could dispense

 

To Doullens & Puchevillers

MARS
Entry.85:
MARDI. 
Having discarded great quantities of carefully collected boot brushes, writing pads, clothing, etc. etc. we fell in about 4pm & marched about 3 miles or more to the railway station of Steenbecque. Here we entrained in cattle trucks & travelled all night obtaining some sleep.
Entry.86:
Arriving at Doullens in the Somme country about 7am we marched out of the town a mile or so & camped for the morning, thereonly being sufficient lorries for the infantry, in the late afternoon we marched to the village of Puchevillers,17 kilometres & were supposed to sleep in a wood, but sneaked off into barns! Most of the villagers had already departed.

To Behencourt & Franvillers, & Gentelles

MARS
Entry.87:
JEUDI. 
We continued to hear multitudinous rumours about enemy advance. All rumours, even from British infantry said how they were continually outflanked & had to retreat becoming disorganized & losing morale.
After dinner we marched about 17 kilometres to the village of Behencourt where we had to pitch our tents but a few of us hired a barn billet.
Entry.88:
28
 
JEUDI
. 
After dinner we marched a fairly short distance to the village of Franvillers then about 5 miles west of Bray on the Somme River. Here we were given barn billets & settled down for the night but at 8pm were given the alarm told to hand in all our gear except blanket, groundsheet & greatcoat & then 20 going by lorry the remainder marched through Corbee & Cachy & Gentelles & slept there

(Self) To Cachy, With 35 th Batt.

MARS
Entry.89:
SAMEDI 
We found the villages of Cachy & Gentelles evacuated by the civilian population Cachy being only about 4-5 kilos from the enemy but both villages undamaged by artillery. We billeted ourselves wherever we likedin the furnished houses but respected the property except that rations being upset we availed ourselves of any food stocks or necessaries.

30 SAMEDI
That afternoon a party of bearers was sent from Gentelles to Cachy to an ads we established there, and with three others – Lcpl Witt, S Shearman and Ron Ponton. I was sent to one of the battalions (35th Bn) We camped in a wood in the rain for some hours & then had a short sleep in some huts by a deserted aerodrome and at 2 am marched into the line Hqrs & the AMC staying in Villers Bretonneux & the others going 7½ kilos.

In line, Villlers Brettoneux (Self)

MARS
Entry.90:
We had marched in at 3am to Villers Brettoneux, a small town about 9 miles east of Amiens. Our sector was fairly quiet but 
the
 one of our battalions which had gone in a little earlier on the right of us (
34th
 33rd) attacked the enemy successfully aided by the 34th B recaptured a good deal of ground. However they suffered severely from machine gun fire & our bearers worked hard for 12 hours. However we did not have many casualties & one of our cars was brought up further so we four had a comparative easy time & found time to explore a warehouse full of champagne, liqueur, champagne wine & tinned meat & vegetables which considerably added to our scanty rations. The rap was first in the front room of a house but later we moved it to a cellar of a large bonnetrie where it was reasonably safe. We 4 were relieved at 4pm & ret'd to Gentelles.

 

Gentelles to Boves
(Men of amb.wounded)

AVRIL
Entry.91:
We remained at Gentelles, that is, the bearers not working with the fighting men – the infantry & machine gun company.
We lived mainly on souvenired rations including some fowls, a calf and potatoes, cocose etc.
We slept mainly in barns. There were some French as well as British troops digging themselves in outside our billets on the edge of the village.
Entry.92:
MARDI. 
As on the preceding day the enemy shelled the village, and, 6 of our men – HG McLean (severely), John Perry, C Wynn, McKay, being wounded properly & some others slightly it was decided to evacuate the billets, so, after dinner, we moved back to Boves on the R Aire and were billeted in a big barn in the main street there. Our mds was already there. Most of the "civvies" had gone

AVRIL
Entry.93:

Entry.227: Quiet day in camp. Resting. Wrote letters. Route
Entry.228:
Quiet day. Route march & little squad-drill
Wrote letters. Posted letters to Mother 2 & Will.

AOUT
Entry.229:
Quiet day.
Cricket match C & A Section Made 4 runs.
We have supper, cocoa & biscuits from comforts Fund every evening at 9pm.
9pm Reg Fry came from lorry park in Bussy½ mile away to see me. We had a good yarn & arranged to go & see him on Tues.
Entry.230:
DIMANCHE. 
Quiet day in dugouts on Amiens-Daours Rd near Daours.

AOUT
Entry.231:
LUNDI. 
Fatigue parade 9am
10am parade marching order. Marched through Daours, Neuville, Corbie to Smiths Farm & had lunch there. Then continued along north bank of Somme thro' Vaux to a ravine where we pitched tents & established the ambulance.
6pm was sent back to Smiths Farm with 12 others on fatigue.
Entry.232:
At Smiths Farm. Went on duty with Jos Gibson, Rab(inovitch), & Harry Tuffy unloading & loading patients at dressing station.
Incidentally we played much auction bridge.
10pm recalled & taken by car through Vaux to ravine off the river road. Here rejoined the ambulance & slept in a bell tent on hill side.
Received Aussy mail of
Entry.233:
AOUT 

21 MERCREDI. 
9am parade in ravine
2pm. fell in & marched about 2 miles in sweltering heat and fearful dust along valley road to Sailly Lorette where we rested for awhile & had tea. Then 16 of us to go with the 35th Battalion again were taken by car up past Chipilly (captured by Eng 9/8/18) Here we remained till dark. 10pm moved into line at RAP about 1000 yds behind line.
(Went 5 miles today)
Entry.234:
Battalion marched in during early morning. We gained 2 or 3 hours rest & a little sleep. Violent enemy shelling. 4 of our 16 chaps were wounded – but none seriously (Flett, Proctor, J Smith, Donovan) Carried back patient to quarry 1 mile back. Then another with aid of prisoners. Then many more ¾ mile to relay post. Tired. 9pm moved with RAP up 1000 yds to correspond with the battalions advance of 1000 yds at 5 am that morning.
(went 10 miles today)

Heard Val Rochford (A Sect) was killed)
(Went 10 miles today)

AOUT
Entry.235:
One
 Two carrys during early morning (one mile back to relay) Returned fagged out completely (although strong).
A lull gave us a sleep till about 11am when we made some tea on"tommy cookers" & had breakfast. We lived in dugouts in a small wooded ravine. Went for walk, saw Bray, led in 2 wounded.
A few more trips to loading post on main road. 9 pm Relieved by B Sect & returned to Quarry on
Entry.236:
Chipilly-Bray Rd
 (Valley Rd) slept in deep dugout till 4am when roused & sent back to relay post since advanced & now also 40th RAP . Conducted 2 carrys with Fritzes to loading post ½ mile away.
Made Fritzes bury one of their men. Then Quiet day at Relay post till told to have a spell at 4pm & returned to Quarry on "Valley Rd". Had tea constructed bunks in same deep dugout & slept there, safe but cold. 10th Brig took Bray at 4am.
(Went 5 miles)

AOUT
Entry.237:
Rose at 11am, cadged cocoa & bread & jam & had breakfast after wash.
12.30pm dinner. Washed towel, shaved etc. Made these entries for 5 days.
Today's additional advance by 10th Brigade has been followed by a big enemy retirement & now this quarry which was well in advance is behind the big guns which were ready.
Entry.238:
Rainy day. After dinner we made ourselves on brazier we marched on straggled 
through Bray
tosome dugouts just the other side. On the way we past a good number more German dead. Our dugouts were near an enemy ammunition & material railhead dump. This was mined.
We played bridge 
all day
 & slept in the dugouts kindly made by Fritz. We were resting while our battalion was out of the line.
Nearby all the bridges had been blown up.

Self in line

AOUT 

27 MARDI. 
Played bridge all day & did cooking. Showery weather.
Enemy still retiring towards Peronne. The scenery around Bray & other villages on the Somme is rather pretty with plenty of foliage showing up the red roofs. The church roof in Bray was painted with the Geneva cross as large as possible.
The village was not altogether ruined.
The people of Eng are said to be elated 100,000 prisoners have been taken since
Entry.239:
28 MERCREDI. 
After breakfast marched 1 mile & joined 40th Batt. Then Had dinner & marched with them 
through
 
Susanne
carrying rations & stretchers & light gear nearly 3 miles & had spell & tea in old British Nissen huts in shallow valley. Wrote these notes for 3 days as everything is so confused one could not remember all for long. Occupied an old dugout & slept there, only one squad having a carry back to Susanne. Shells falling around. Another battalion of 10th Bge advanced about 2000 yards.

(Sn Woodham)
To Susanne Self in line
Entry.241:
9am marched behind headquarters of battalion carrying stretchers about 2-3 miles up Somme towards line. Stayed near quarry about 2000 yds behind where enemy was supposed to be. Carrying during day down to loading post at 
CURLU
. Another C Sec party with 37th Batt suffered. Snowy Woodham killed. Gates, Sullivan, Howard (Wagstaffe) wounded.
9pm Moved a mile nearer line & found dugout & obtained some sleep near Curlu.
Entry.242:
8am we moved with RAP about 1 mile nearer the line. The loading post was moved up nearly to the place we left. Had about 3 carries each during day without prisoners.
Violent enemy shelling. (Going into line we narrowly escaped machine gunfire) The RAP consisted of two small dugouts cut into top of slope of valley near Cléry. We carried down the valley→ the l post being later¾ mile away. This valley was always shelled

(Wilf Boys Alby Clarkson Eb Rabinovitch)

AOUT
Entry.243:
On the previous night one of our squads from the RAP had been blown up by a shell. Wilfy Boys & Alby Clarkson, two fine chaps were killed & the fourth man Jos Gibson coming back for help, we found the third man Pte EH Rabinovitch & carried him badly wounded to a RAP. However he died 
the next
 during the day.
Soon after daylight the 3rd 5th & 2nd divvies attacked advancing far & capturing many prisoners whom we made work for the rest of the morning carrying the wounded including many of the enemy. The shellfire relaxed a bit during the day. Our men captured Mont St Quentin, dominating Peronne. The prisoners were Prussians mostly Augusta's (Empress of G) & Alexander's (Czar) Regs. They were middle class prisoners & glad to be captured. I had conversation & much amusement with them. Others wounded days earlier were Flood, Birch, Stuckley, Taylor (B Sec)

SEPTEMBRE
Entry.244:
Had spent the night in our little funk holes at the RAP . About 6am we followed Batt'n HQrs out of the line & marched back about 2½ miles to their horse lines at 
CURLU
. Here we rested for the day, the infantry being well cared for by their cooks Q Masters etc & given a liberal rum ration.
Our staff sergt Carr brought us our Aussy mail 17 June & we were happy. Slept cold in dugout we found.
Entry.245:
8am. Went over to (10th F Amb) ADS . Had breakfast there. Told to be a loading party but cleared out, caught a motor lorry back to our ambulance MDS at 
Susanne
.
Billeted in tents erected by our reinforcements already arrived.
Had easy day resting. Should have written letters but did not feel like it. Visited cemetery in neighbourhood to see Woodham's & Rab's graves. The small cemetery contained two enemy

gun positions also horse lines, two new deep dugouts under the graves

SEPTEMBRE
Entry.246:
At Susanne east of Bray, on river Somme's north bank.
2pm Parade for clothing. Obtained new breeches. Visited the village church. Saw vault of local nobility which had been broken open by the huns. The partitions had been forced & fittings seemingly removed from the old coffins.

4 MERCREDI. 
Parade 9am. Pay Parade 10.30
2pm Parade for web equipment.
4pm found new abode – a back room with 5 bunks. Very comfortable in it. Wrote letters. Rec'd parcel no 13 fr home

3 Mard
i Attended "buckshee" "Cooees" Pierrot show in Old Chateau Hall used by huns as stables.
Their prisoners had to clean it out though. 6.15 the cage is cleared & the prisoners march away doing the goose step past our Div Headqrs.

Bearers to Curlu
Entry.248:
At Susanne, spelling.
Were refitted for shortages.
Lost my fountain pen Will gave me.

Entry.250:
Bearers marched 
from Susanne by night to Curlu
 further up the river.
There we were in 
divisional
corps reserve and were billeted in a german hut formerly meat store and dugouts built by the enemy & comfortably furnished by him long before.

SEPTEMBRE 

7 SAMEDI. 
We are beside the river which is here ¾ mile wide with the canal one side & the natural course separated by a wide expanse of low & partly marshy ground. Most of the chaps have a swim in the ponds of the river but I only ventured (very gladly too) to the hot baths installed 
at a
by our battalions at a former german hut.
Entry.251:
Harold Best & I have salvaged British rifles & ammunition & go out duck shooting. There are ducks about but they are too fly for all. All we can get are black water hens.
We got 3. Harold swimming for them. We plucked them as well as possible & cooked them in a borrowed dixie lid over a fire we made, gave 1 to the the cooks & 
enjoyed
 the other 2

SEPTEMBRE 

9 LUNDI. 
We amused ourselves a good deal shooting but even the water hens are not plentiful and have been mostly frightened away. We play bridge & write letters but the nights are cold & dark & the weather rainy. We are well out of the line.
Entry.252:
The second Aust Divin is carrying on or was, the good work commenced by the 3rd. The germans are being rapidly driven back & we are 
now
far behind the line even the line of balloons making us look like base depot men.

To Hallé near Peronne
Entry.254:
Hallé village has disappeared as it was just in rear of the French front of 1916 to which the enemy drove in 1914.
The old battlefield with trenches & dugouts and still some scattered equipment is still of interest & I explored it gaining good views from the high ground here. The views up & down the Somme which bends here are glorious.

12 JEUDI. 
Showery
We marched with kit from 
Curlu toward Peronne to Hallé
 a village 2 kilometres nearer than Peronne. We marched through Hem & Cléry two places which were once fair sized villages but now only heaps of bricks level with the ground.
Hallé was not so destroyed and many of the houses are still tenable. In addition the enemy had built many cosy

Visited Mt St Quentin taken by 5th Batt
Entry.256:
little rooms onto the houses which were also repaired & roofed again with malthoid.
Also there were a large number of dugouts and cellars converted into such.
This place Hallé had evidently been a headquarters.
In the large farm we took for a brigade hospital was about½ a ton of printed maps.
Entry.257:
Three of us found a house with a few rooms dry & unspoilt. And here we were very comfortable having straw bunks and table, chairs, fire etc.
I went for walk with Alf H & Bill Pearson to the top of that extensive wooded eminence known as Mt St Quentin. It had been enemy stronghold as evidenced by the belts of wire & the number of buried enemy dead.

SEPTEMBRE
Entry.258:
Mont St Quentin was captured by the 24th Battalion, 2nd Divvy on 31st August. I 
belie
 saw a site chosen on it by the 2nd Divvy for a memorial. From the hill a fine view is obtained, especially of Peronne.
Entry.260:
Bathing parade to baths past Peronne. I dropped out & explored Peronne. Not half the houses are ruined but all are absolutely empty except for the living requirements of the flown Boches.
A very large French barracks still stands little harmed & was extensively used by the enemy.

18 MERCREDI. 
Quiet day at Hallé
Pitching & unpitching tents.
The total of prisoners captured by the Allies on this front has reached 175,000 since
Entry.262:
Resting at Hallé
7.45am Physical training
Morning. Helped make cricket pitch & fill in shell holes on ground.
Aft Played in 9 F Amb XI against 34th Batt (including Harold Lilya) We were beaten 128 to 50. I made 0 like about 7 of us.
Evening: Played draughts by log fire.
Entry.264:
21 SAMEDI. 
Walked over1 mile to 33rd Battalion Sports. Entered for visitors race 100 yards off scratch. Came second.
Entry.265:
No church service. Parades as usual.

SEPTEMBRE
Entry.266: Sent parcel home containing 2 enemy caps, shoulderstraps, badges, coins, cartridges.
Entry.267:
Played cricket with 9 F Amb against 7 Brigade Headquarters. Beaten 72-48

SEPTEMBRE
Entry.269:
Sent parcel home containing enemy gas mask, paper strap, maps

To line behind Ronssoy.
Entry.271:
Quiet day at Hallé
6.30pm: Warned for line
9.30pm moved off in battle order (equipment)
Marched through Peronne along Bapaume Rd thence thro' Bussu & Villers Faulcon & St Emille arriving 3am in a sunken road far from everywhere. Here some of us found dugouts and we slept as well as possible to dawn.

28 SAMEDI. 
till 3am. Here we were about 5 miles behind the line which was in front of Ronssoy.
We were near the big guns & just behind the line of our observation balloons.
Not being detailed to a battalion, I helped get the rations ready for the morning. Slept till →

One of our tanks burned all day & all night & was as a guiding beacon (night 29-30th)
(The tent subdivisions established dressing station at Ronssoy later)

SEPTEMBRE
Entry.272:
← till 5am when 16 bearers from each section joined 33rd (A) 34th (B Sec), & 35th (C Section) Battalion & the remaining bearers including Nobby, Alf H, & myself marched under Major Fitzpatrick through RONSSOY also some gas & stray machine gun bullets & stayed in position near some tanks one being mined. Dawn Americans had advanced 3000 yds but did not mop up the enemy m guns.
8pm Dark: I joined 35th Batt RAP in support trenches
Entry.273:
LUNDI. 
in place of Milton who had been wounded. Spent night on stairs of deep dugout 5am: Followed batt out of line & in again by daylight about 1 mile further south, where we remained in support position. One carry 1½ miles to Ford loading post. Found pair Fritz field glasses in trench. Returned to RAP in trench near disabled tank in valley. Many derelict tanks about. Slept in enemy dugout 30ft.underground. Americans remain cut off 200 yards forward.

Armistace with Bulgaria takes effect on Sept 30th/18.

OCTOBRE
Entry.274:
Quiet day in RAP in trench. Went to loading post advanced to Bellicourt Rd. for water. Ground strewn with dead mostly Americans.
News reaches us that Bulgaria has accepted our drastic 
peace
 terms for armistice. The news from all parts of the front is good. On our south the 5th Aussies have advanced splendidly.
5pm. We moved with battalion to trenches forward & to our left. No casualties.
Entry.275: After good sleep in comfortable German dugout. Spent a quiet day without carries. Our position was to the north & rear of the village of Bony which had been cleared by the
Entry.276:
Divvy . We were thus in portion of the Hindenburg Line while the divvy occupied portion of the main line with its tunnels concrete emplacement etc.
5pm. Battalion marched out & camped 5 miles or more behind line.
Slept in deep British tunnel dugout.

Nights are very cold & slightly frosty

OCTOBRE 

3 JEUDI. 
Breakfast with 35th Battalion. Marched back to wood about 4 or 5 miles further back.
7pm. Recalled to ambulance camped nearby after they had marched from Ronssoy where they had an A.D.S. 
The tents had not arrived so we found nissen huts empty in a large quarry. Slept there.
Entry.277:
Quiet day in quarry.

To Neuville-au-Bois

OCTOBRE
Entry.278:
At quarry on Peronne- Road
4pm Marched from camp near quarry. Entrained on light railway following along main road to Peronne. Marched to station, waited in cellar playing bridge, & entrained 30 to a cattle truck about 11pm.
Entry.279:
Slept crowded in cattle truck.
7am arived at 
Airaines
 a village about 10 miles SW of Abbeville. Marched 9 miles thro' very pretty country like Southern England to the small wooded village of 
Neuville au Bois
Here billleted in top rooms of outbuilding of the small chateau.
The French papers proclaimed Germany Austria-H & Turkeys desire for general armistice & peace. Made straw matting for bed.

OCTOBRE
Entry.280:
Quiet day at Neuville-au-Bois.
The weather is now mild but always cloudy & sometimes showery.
Walked into Oisemont, a large village 2 kilos away.
Had hot bath in hot condensed water from engines of large hessian factory 1 kilo away. Very appreciable.
Found windfall apples first fresh fruit for a long time.
Entry.281:
Afternoon. Walked 7 kilometres or 5 miles to Hallincourt, a large village & divisional headquarters. Was unable to procure a meal owing to the population being rationed in food supplies.
Walked back in dark.
Harold Best back from leave brought me a fountain pen (WHS) )

OCTOBRE
Entry.282:
Quiet day at Neuville au Bois.
Arranged mess for 8 so that one being orderly each day could draw the food at cook house 200 yards away.
Entry.283:
Neuville-au-Bois is a fairly small village 
just off
 near the small town of Oisemont about 12 miles South of Abbeville.
It is situated on high ground apparently fertile. The village consists of a church, chateau & about 
30 or 40
 50 houses, & barns & stables. Many refugees from Amiens etc. are housed here also. Cows are kept in twos & threes & taken out to pasture & minded there.

daily by old women & children. There are few men in the village.

OCTOBRE
Entry.284:
8 of us, (later reduced to 5) hired a room in the house of an old French girl who was not hospitable at first, but friendly later when received bacon, cheese etc we did not want. Rent 10 frs a week.
Here we had almost the comforts of home, with table, chairs, fire kerosene lamp, & desirable out-look on small lawn. Nice & private, but brick floor cold.
Entry.285:
SAMEDI. 
Here we have all meals, write letters during day, play bridge, cribbage etc in evenings, have supper of our own cooking before retiring to "our rooms" at the château to sleep. Of course we have to "acquire" coal, wood, kerosene, fat, flour etc. Our cooking includes apple & meat pies, pancakes, scones fried bread, toast, cocoa etc. We buy fresh milk daily. We do our own housework & have the room to ourselves.

OCTOBRE
Entry.286:
Our landlady is Mme Canaples She runs the house, the dog the old man her husband & looks after her cripple son & daughter Georgina.
The hubby about 55 works at factory (hessian) a kilo away. So does the girl. (about 22). She is plain but a good girl, more amusing than interesting
Entry.287:
Our routine is reveille (? I don't know). Breakfast 8am. Parade for inspection & fatigues 9am Dinner 12.30 pm
Parade 2pm for sports. We sometimes attend this.
The educational parade for students will be 10.30 am with classes to 11.20 & 11.20-12.30. There 
are
 will also be French & Eng classes at night.

OCTOBRE
Entry.288:
The village is orthodox. The chateau has a pleasant aspect. The owner is at the war & our officers have the use of most of it. Its park or wood is very fine with fine avenues.
The stables are for about 30-40 horses & very fine.
At one cross roads is a crucifix with about 100 small wooden crosses
Entry.289:
which have been deposited upon it as deaths have occurred in the village. These crosses are unmarked by names. At the other cross roads is a concrete representation of saints (women) praying to the Virgin Mary.
There are sometimes candles burning. There is also a more used shrine in the centre of the village.

OCTOBRE
Entry.290:
On fatigue party to our hospital down at Vaux-Marquenville a village 1 Kilometre away. We have many patients owing to Spanish influenza. 
We
 Hospital occupies a deserted farm in desolate surroundings even the stable being used for accommodating patients.
Did a good days work

circa 18 VENDREDI. 
Was obliged to hand in leggins I had a year & receive a pair of puttees which happen to be good woollen ones & look very smart.
Entry.292:
Resting at Hallé on Somme
7.15am parade physical training
Entry.294: Bought German automatic pistol from Lyall Walker for 60 francs £2/5/-. He had bought in from J Beckett for 60 frs
Entry.295:
Attended dentist. Capt Foote. Ernie Fowler, orderly

OCTOBRE
Entry.296:
Commenced teaching under unit educational scheme.
Taught Trigonometry to 6 students & book keeping to 20.
Am to teach trig once geom once & book keeping twice a week to rest of ambulance. Don't mind teaching as men are keen & sensible.

24 JEUDI. 
Leave to Abbeville. Left at 10.30am 30 of us taken in lorry 8 miles to Abbeville. Spent day there. Visited cathedral (17th Centy half 
fini
 built & very poor) & squares one damaged by bomb.
Visited market stalls in square & walked all round. Went out to 3rd A G Hosp 1½ kilos out of town. Returned to tea 
e
 (2 eggs 2/6). Went to Anzac Cooes. Very poor show. Bus 8 pm. Return in dark. Home supper.
Entry.298:
Teaching Bookkeeping in morn
Attended dentist.
Entry.300:
Attended service in German marquee in by our cookhouse (C of E)
We never see any but C of E chaplains.
Entry.301:
Attended evangelical meeting by Chaplain Solf at Citerne in evening.
In morning taught book-keeping.
Attended dentist.

OCTOBRE
Entry.303:
Attended dentist.
Evening. Walked to Citerne village 2 miles off to bible class. Not held.
"Gutzer".

OCTOBRE
Entry.304:
Captain Foote fixed a front Davis crown for me. I had obtained it thro' him from Claudius Ash & Sons.
It looks very well.

NOTES D'OCTOBRE 
October
 this year was beautiful weather with one or two short wet spells.
We have spent the month very quietly but comfortably (because of our hired living room) at our little village Neuville au Bois near Oisemont south of Abbeville (near coast).
The war news is full of victories & hauls of easily obtained prisoners.

NOVEMBRE
Entry.305: Received a prize of 10 francs for 2nd in Visitors Race 33rd Battalion's sports at Peronne
Entry.306:
We hear of Turkeys armistice dating from noon yesterday.
Handy, as we are all stony 

2 SAMEDI. 
On cookhouse fatigue from 7am.
From 11-12 noon all men had to be in billets or have a pass. Military police to round up all stragglers said to be to catch men in Aust uniform who have been waylaying & robbing.
Evening
.Walked to Oisemont with Ern, Ted & Harold. Bought slippers (5.50 frs.) for sports.

NOVEMBRE
Entry.307:
Quiet Sunday. On fatigue sterilising blankets. No service. Got up early in morning & had a practice for coming sports.
Pay day. Drew 80 francs
Entry.308:
Fine day. Leaves on ground are dead. Watched soccer match. Had a kick snaps.
No classes held in morning as students on fatigues & 30 away in Abbeville on leave.
Rumours say we go to the front up north in two weeks time.
Armistice with Austria in force today. News reaches us tomorrow.

NOVEMBRE
Entry.309:
Wet day. Fatigue. Saw Spence Steele now Lieut about education. Chas Hamblin visited village but I did not see him.
Evening. More good news in paper 13000 prisoners taken by British & French.
1st Divvy goes "back forward"

Pastry (peach pie) & scones for tea & supper. Ted Figtree's make
Rumours
Entry.311: Charlie Hamblin dropped in for the evening & we had a yarn around the fire.
Entry.313:
10 DIMANCHE. 
Lovely weather these days.
Ran off 100 yd tests to determine team for relay race for brigade sports.
Obtained place in team of 4.

News reached us at 9am of Armistice signed with Germany at 5am
Gladness but no excitement

NOVEMBRE 

11 LUNDI. 
No Classes held. Rested in morning. Afternoon went to Brigade sports to represent 9th Amb in relay race but as the race was lengthened to 440's, 220 & 100 yards I stood out.
Our team came third.
Two of our chaps went to Paris without leave. Later returned 2 or 3 days later & OK.

12 MARDI. 
Training every day for our sports on Thursday.
Dieting also. No smoking.

NOVEMBRE 

13 MERCREDI. 
Pay Parade. Drew 40 frs.
Squared all debts. No classes held.
Divisional sports held.

14 JEUDI. 
Frosty morning. Lovely day.
10am - 4.30 pm we held our unit sports in a paddock.
I ran in wheelbarrow race 2nd in heat, champ 100 yds (3rd in best heat) 220 yds champ (1st) obstacle race (1st to apples then 4th) relay race. (C Sec lost to A Sec by yard). Team Wag Best Pearson McLean. H Best 2nd in long jump & 100 yds h'cap. Perce Burdon (1st) & Wag
Entry.316:
Heavy frost but sunny day.
After dinner Charlie Hearne & a friend of his James of 9 B HQ came to see me & have a yarn.
Morning taught bookk'g
Entry.317:
Heavy hoar frost. Lovely sunny day. Frost only thawed in a few sunny parts & set hard again by 4pm. Very cold evening colder than any in Sydney.
Friend of Alf H's came from 8th F Amb Pte 
Rees
 Watts 8 F Amb
Rumours are that we move on Tuesday next.
Paris & London are regaining former brilliance.
Entry.319:
Coldest day so far. The village pond is frozen over & the ground remained without signs of thawing all day. Evening walked to Oisemont. During the day on cook's fatigue.
Dinner Roast beef, roast potatoes, beans, onions, sausages.
There are plenty of furfies flying about..
Entry.320:
We were officially told the other 4 Aussy divisions here were included in the 4th British Army of Occupation & were going into Germany.
Our division is to go forward in Belgium and to be the ceremonial division among the Aussies so we are told.
Visited our hospital to have carbuncle on calf dressed.
Entry.322: Living quietly at Neuville au Bois. The unit classes are languishing.
Entry.323:
At our mess at Neuville au-Bois

NOVEMBRE
Entry.324: Ground frozen for a number of days & village pond frozen one day.
Entry.325:
Very cold, clear & frosty nights
The other AIF divisions have gone up
 

NOVEMBRE
Entry.326:
Parades:
9.30 (inspection)
10.30 (education) No one attends
2.30 (sports) some attend.
Entry.327:
NOVEMBRE 

25 LUNDI. 
The educational classes are finis.
Received Xmas parcel from Chookie.
Entry.328:
The other 4 AIF divisions have gone up Charleroi towards Belgium & Germany.

("Nach Paris") Self to 3rd AGH 
Abbeville
Entry.330:
At Neuville-au-Bois. With Harold Best.
Attended sick parade unnecessarily for eye-glasses. Received pay 40 fr. Packed valise. Completed a day in 'life' of an amb SB for divisional competition & War Records. 1.30pm by Ambulance Car to 3rd AGH at Abbeville. Admitted to Ward A4.
Evg. Walked down to Cooees in Old Theatre Abbeville. Fine show. Ret'd hosp slept in bed
Entry.331:
in marquees joined together
11am Interviews doctor.
Card marked for Noyelles for glasses. The day is wet & windy. Met Charlie Baxter, Harold Best's friend. Helped in dressing room. I had carbuncle on wrist being fomented & cured.
In Evg good concert in fine YMCA hut at the hospital.
Later went to BEF canteen for biscuits & cigarettes for the morrow.

(Paris)
Entry.332:
The tucker at the hospital is poor
11am. Harold & I cleared out of hospital walked 4 miles to Pont Remy near Abbeville & caught 2.20 pm train for Paris.
Terribly crowded train. Arrived in dark 7.30pm at Gare du Nord. Dodged MP's by crossing platforms. Went to Leave Club Place de la Republique. Supper.
Took room at private Hotel Paris. France nearly at 10 frs per day.
Entry.333:
Light (French) breakfast at hotel. Went to Leave Club. Went with party of 50 from there by underground & electric train to Versailles. Dinner there. Visited Palace of Versailles – Hall of Mirrors, Battle Room, Throne Room Reception Rooms. The Royal Chapel then Hall of Battles. Beautiful gardens (now winter), lakes canals fountains. Saw Colonel Jolly & wife. Returned Club. Went with part to the Opera

Romeo & Juliette – Very fine. Unruly orchestra. Then supper at club & to hotel to bed.

DECEMBRE
Entry.334:
Breakfast 10am as usual at hotel.
Went to Club. Walked Boule Magenta to Gare du Nord. Dinner at Club.
Went with large party river trip up & now Seine thro' the city to St. Cloud. Then took tram & metro back to Eiffel Tower.
Walked to La Concorde. Metros to Maillot to see Luna Park (closed)
Dinner at Duvals at Maillot. 8.30 Gaumont Palace (pictures). Late.
By necessity Taxi to Republique. to Hotel to bed.
Entry.335:
B'fast & Dinner. Metro to Opera walked Madeline Church (fine)
Walked Concorde Champs Elysées. Petit et Grand Palais. Bde des Pres Wilson to Trocadero. U-ground to Place D'Etoile Arc de Triomphe. Walked Elysées. U-ground to Maillot & Bois de Boulogue. Metro to Louvre Tuilleries, Place Vendome to Corner of Blighty (Club)
8.30 Casino de Paris – poor show. Jazz band Dear Cigarettes, Metro to Leave Club. Supper Bed.

(Paris)
DECEMBRE
Entry.336:
Left Hotel. Paid bill 56 fr for two. Club. 
W
 Metro to Bastille. Walked thro' poorer quarters to Pere Lachaise Cemetery & Place Gambetta. Metro Place Nation. Metro Tuilleries Vendome & Salvation Army Club for dinner. Metro Hotel de Ville. Notre Dame. P de Justice. Jardin de Luxembourg. Senate. Les Invalides (closed), Ch Deputies, Bridges & Concorde bright at night. Club. Concert. Gare du Nord. Meal Canteen. Train 10.15pm

4 MERCREDI. 
Paris far behind. Arrived Abbeville 4.30am. Walked in dark to hospital, got into bed.
8am breakfast
10am Up before CO for being away. Remanded to unit on charge of being a patient AWL from 10pm 29/11/18 to 6pm
Entry.337:
Quiet day in hospital. Wrote home lengthily.

DECEMBRE
Entry.338:
Meanwhile ambulance has moved 20 kilos from Neuville au Bois to village of Valines about 20 kilos ESE of Abbeville.

 
3pm Discharged
Quiet day in hospital
Entry.340:
10am. From hospital: Motor char-a-banc to Noyelles at Mouth of Somme to eye specialist at Chinese labor camp hospital there.
Glasses ordered 1.00 & 1.25 myoptic. Eyes examined with drops. Dinner there.
3.30 Returned by char a banc.
Evng went Pictures & later round to see Brom Bieler.
Entry.341:
Quiet day in hospital.
Wrote letters in YMCA
Evng. Went round to see Brom Bieler & have a chat.

To Valines Self to unit

DECEMBRE
Entry.342:
Quiet day in hospital.
Talked with Fritz prisoners & obtained a few souvenirs to send home.
Evening: went to pictures EFC show near Abbeville.
Left 2 films in Abbe to be developed.
Today, the ambulance moved 20 kilos from Neuville to the village of Valines
 20 kilos ESE of Abbeville.
Entry.343:
Quiet morning in hospital.
Donned khaki. Drew new hat (no good) & puttees.
3.30pm caught ambulance car at hospital 
back to unit at Valines
. Tea.
Found mates & billets in dark.
4 parcels & 25 Sept letters waiting for me. Good yarn in mates mess –
Slept in barn. No orderly room proceedings in sight.

At DHQ 

DECEMBRE
Entry.344:
I was instructed by orderly room to pack up & go to DHQ to do some accountancy work for divisional canteens.
Went after dinner by Ford Car to DHQ at Oisemont. Saw Major Bartram. He told me to see him any time I wanted to. I am to help Lieut Irwin who is away on leave.
Billeted myself with chap Haskins of ADMS office in a room
Entry.345:
in the house of 2 very kind old French people in the town.
Aged 62 & 60 they spent 4 & 3½ yrs resp in German hands & have suffered much but are happy withal. They make us very much at home.
The house is practically unfurnished. We sleep on floor in attic.
Irwin being away I have nothing to do.

 

At DHQ 

DECEMBRE
Entry.346:
Lazy day doing nothing.
Have drawn pay been for bath & ordered 6 official photos.
Yarned & dined with the old couple who are very kind to us having suffered themselves.
Wrote home.
Entry.347:
Lazy day doing nothing. Irwin returns today.
Market day in the town.

At DHQ
Entry.350:
The office is very convenient with windows, electric light & fire all near table 
sut
 situated at extreme window on left front of first floor (facing Mairie).
I went to unit for orderly proceedings re Paris trip. Was admonished but ordered to forfeit 12 days pay. time taken over proceedings.
Entry.351:
The Headquarters clerks including G & Q Staffs, Divvy Pay Office, Post Office & Camp Commandants Office have a mess. Many are corporals.
I belong to this mess. We pay 10 francs a pay & have proper mess arrangements & pretty good tucker. There is also a "mens mess" for runners, orderlies, batmen etc.

At DHQ 

DECEMBRE
Entry.352:
Visited dentist of 11 F Amb at Biencourt. Walked there and back (10 miles) partly in the rain. He reset the Davis crown Capt Bennet set for me a year ago & replaced cement filling of gold backed crown (broken)
Wrote letters at office
Entry.353:
Went to Abbeville (about 10 miles on business for DHQ to buy 100 sheets of paper.
Bought a Hall & Knights H Algebra at the YMCA bookstall for myself.
Returned by lorry to Hallencourt & had to walk to Oisemont 6 miles.

At DHQ 

DECEMBRE
Entry.354:
Quiet day at DHQ at Oisemont.
Went on bike 9 kilos to Divisional Canteen a message.
Market day at Oisemont. All the women from the farms of the district gather round the butter egg meat vegetable fancy goods & footwear stalls. The latter come in caravan carts.
A scissors grinder does great business. Studied Algebra.
Entry.355:
Performed the usual fairly small amount of accounts & clerical work at H.Q.
Yarned with Madame as usual over coffee.
The address is
M.
Instituteur Etraité
à Oisemont (Somme)
France

DECEMBRE
Entry.356:
The weather remains rainy but splendid for the season of the year being comparatively warm without frosts or snow.
All the other Australian Divisions are up near Charleroi behind the British armies of occupation in Germany.
Entry.357:
To journey to our ambulance now at Valines. 20 kilometres (12½ miles) distance I went by gs waggon to the central Store of the divisional canteen in the centre of the divvy area.
From here I went by a limber nearly out to the amb & walked the remainder. Met all my cobbers at the amb & had a great yarn. They have a 
billet
 hired mess room in a French house but have to 

quit it by 8.30 pm every evening. Slept in barn billet with blankets borrowed from hospital

DECEMBRE 

25 MERCREDI.
Entry.358:
No parade for ambulance.
A lovely sunny morning with a speckle of windy-snow. We yarned till dinner time at 1pm & then adjourned to the school which was arranged for & finely decorated by us for the occasion. Had a fine dinner to a printed menu – Col Maguire dropped in. Tea in mess together.
Eving, a dance in school room.
Slept in billet.
Entry.359:
Stayed with mates & C Boyall (Lieut 33rd) who had come over to see us till 2.30pm & caught 3pm train to Eu. A very pretty run of about 40 minutes in the train. Visited church at Eu & saw town then caught train down to Le Tréport.
Walked round beach & break water, had tea found a room & went to picture show.
Le Tréport is very interesting. Its chalky cliffs are attractive.

DECEMBRE
Entry.360:
At Le Tréport. Ascended by the cable railway at 45° up the cliff to the headland above from which the views were glorious. Walked down past the Town Hall & round to the beach of Mers-les-Bains with its pretty fronted residences.
Took 11am train to Gamaches waited there 3 hours in Café & caught 3pm train to Oisemont.
Evening worked. All OK.
Entry.361:
Quiet day at DHQ
No work to do.
Weather still rainy but wonderful for the season.
No snow & practically No frost so far.

DECEMBRE
Entry.362:
Quiet day at DHQ
The market days in the village here (Oisemont). All the farmers around bring their spare stock one day now & again & have an auction sale (also many drunks)
Every Saturday is market day & the village square is filled with stalls selling butter, eggs, meat fancy goods, footware etc and
Entry.363:
all the old girls of the township & surrounding villages gather together to do their shopping and then gossip till the rain or dark about 4.45 drives them home.
Meat averages about 3/6 lb Eggs 5d each.
Bread & sugar are still obtained by ration cards but bread is buyable without as well.

Home news has been grand for 1918. May it be so in the year to come, till we are happily united once more.

DECEMBRE
